    1.10 Signal Analysis-Commands

    1.10.1 DDCEConfig

    GET: Query parameters for individual DDC (instance of DDC Signal Extraction [DDCE]).
    SET: Configure DDC.
    Conditions: Parameter DDCEConfig.eState does not apply in DF mode Scan: DDCEConfig.eState=DDCE_STATE_OFF.
    Example: DDCE 1 deactivated,
    frequency 98.5 MHz,
    DDCE coupling function off,
    bandwidth 300 kHz.

    Through frequency coupling, the distance in frequencies between DDCEConfig.iFrequency (DDCE center frequency) and MeasureSettingsFFM.iFrequency (main tuner center frequency) will be held constant by the device itself. If

  • enabled, the DDCE center frequency will be altered automatically whenever the main tuner center frequency is altered. However, you still can modify DDCEConfig.iFrequency to define a new frequency distance from DDCE center frequency to main tuner center frequency
  • disabled, the DDCE center frequency remains set even if MeasureSettingsFFM.iFrequency is altered.

    • If a DDC is bound to Short-Time Synthesizer, arbitrary setting of frequency, frequency coupling and bandwidth is disabled. Bandwidth is configured for all DDCs in total with command ShortTimeSynthesizer instead.


    See also:
  • Command MeasureSettingsFFM (configure FFM measure settings),
  • Command ShortTimeSynthesizer (configure Short-Time Synthesizer),
  • Command DDCEControl (configure all DDCs in total).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    id int32 iDdceIdx Index of DDCE: 1 to 128.
    i/o eDDCE_STATE eState Activate (enable), deactivate (disable) or bind selected DDCE to Short-Time Synthesizer.
    i/o int64 iFrequency Set frequency [Hz] of selected DDCE.
    i/o eSTATE eFrequencyCoupling Switch DDCE coupling function of frequency on or off.
    i/o eDDCE_BW eBandwidth Set bandwidth of selected DDCE.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEConfig">
        <Param name="iDdceIdx">1</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEConfig">
        <Param name="iDdceIdx">1</Param>
        <Param name="eState">DDCE_STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="iFrequency">98500000</Param>
        <Param name="eFrequencyCoupling">STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="eBandwidth">DDCE_BW_300000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEConfig">

    1.10.2 DDCEControl

    GET: Query parameters for all DDCs (instances of DDC Signal Extraction [DDCE]) in total.
    SET: Configure all DDCs in total.
    Conditions: Parameter DDCEControl.iSignalDelay does not apply in DF mode Scan.
    Example: No transfer of DDCE data,
    no IF signal input delay,
    no gain control mechanism.

    The state DDCEControl.eGainControl only takes effect when the DDCE bank is configured to deliver samples in 16-bit mode: DDCEControl.eRemoteMode=DDCE_REMOTE_MODE_SHORT. This mode requires a re-quantization of samples to 16 bit resolution (internally a higher resolution is used). With having DDCEControl.eGainControl

  • disabled, the output samples get quantized by using the 16 most significant bits; this, however, can result in underflows when processing low-level input signals
  • enabled, the internally available samples are analyzed per blocks of 240 samples (good for one output frame each) in order to determine a best possible rescaling factor and then scaled before outputting. This assures the 16-bit output width be used as efficiently as possible. Note that the applied rescaling factor causes a modification of the Data Header field AntennaVoltageRef.RxAttenuation ( AMMOS IF DDCE data stream) in order to assure level accuracy.

    • See also:
  • Command DDCEConfig (configure individual DDC).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eDDCE_REMOTE_MODE eRemoteMode Set mode (format 16 bit or 32 bit) of or disable digital IF transfer via remote control interface.
    i/o int64 iSignalDelay Set delay [s] (range 0 to 2048: 0 s to 34 min 8 s) of IF signal input to all DDCEs.
    out int64 iSignalDelayCurrent Return current value [s] used internally (the closest one possible to requested value).
    i/o eSTATE eGainControl Enable or disable selected gain control mechanism applied to create output samples.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEControl">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEControl">
        <Param name="eRemoteMode">DDCE_REMOTE_MODE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="iSignalDelay">0</Param>
        <Param name="iSignalDelayCurrent">0</Param>
        <Param name="eGainControl">STATE_OFF</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEControl">
        <Param name="eRemoteMode">DDCE_REMOTE_MODE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="iSignalDelay">0</Param>
        <Param name="eGainControl">STATE_OFF</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="DDCEControl">
        <Param name="iSignalDelayCurrent">0</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.10.3 HRPan

    GET: Query HRPan (High-Resolution Panorama) parameters.
    SET: Configure HRPan.
    Example: No transfer of HRPan data,
    step width selected automatically,
    averaging period 655.36 ms,
    averaging period used internally 655.36 ms,
    granularity for averaging period values 160 µs.

    Parameter HRPan.iAvgTimeGranularity: When averaging, the unit forms one single spectrum from all individual spectra emerged (calculated internally) within the specified time span. Mind that exact adhering to this desired span length commonly is not achievable, rather the R&S DDFx will use a value as close as possible to the configured one. From that, HRPan.iAvgTimeGranularity tells the minimum amount of time that HRPan.iAvgTime has to be altered by in order to cause an actual change of averaging time.

    Find more detailed information about High-Resolution Panorama and the dedicated data trace HRPan in the R&S DDFx system manual.

    This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eHRPAN_MODE eMode Enable data stream HRPAN and set data mode to 16 bit (output spectral level information at 16 bit integer), or disable data stream.
    i/o eSTATE eStepAuto Select HRPan step size (channel spacing) to be set automatically (depending on IF panorama span: on) or explicitly (off).
    i/o eHRPAN_STEP eStep Set HRPan step size.
    i/o int64 iAvgTime Set averaging period [µs].
    out int64 iAvgTimeCurrent Return current averaging period value [µs] used internally closest possible to requested value.
    out int64 iAvgTimeGranularity Return current granularity [µs] for averaging period values.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="HRPan">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="HRPan">
        <Param name="eMode">HRPAN_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="eStepAuto">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="eStep">HRPAN_STEP_6250HZ</Param>
        <Param name="iAvgTime">655360</Param>
        <Param name="iAvgTimeCurrent">655360</Param>
        <Param name="iAvgTimeGranularity">160</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="HRPan">
        <Param name="eMode">HRPAN_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="eStepAuto">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="eStep">HRPAN_STEP_6250HZ</Param>
        <Param name="iAvgTime">655360</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="HRPan">
        <Param name="iAvgTimeCurrent">655360</Param>

    1.10.4 ShortTimeDetector

    GET: Query Short-Time Detector (STD) parameter set.
    SET: Configure Short-Time Detector parameter set.
    Conditions: Some parameters do not apply in DF mode Scan or have a modified meaning.
    Example: Short-Time Detector on,
    parameter set ID 0 (Rx mode/FFM),
    step width selected manually to 390.63 Hz,
    range of signal durations 50 µs to 500 ms,
    currently used 500 µs to 500 ms,
    granularity 100 µs each,
    select noise threshold manually,
    noise averaging time 1 ms.

    NOTE 1: In case of a parameter set used for a scan range ( ShortTimeDetector.iStParamSetId = 1 to 64), all parameters except ShortTimeDetector.eState and .eStepAuto have to be set.
    NOTE 2: All modifications to input parameters are only taken over when performing a transition of ShortTimeDetector.eState from OFF to ON.
    NOTE 3: If also using ShortTimeSynthesizer , it must be enabled before enabling Short-Time Detector.

    See also:
  • Command ShortTimeSynthesizer (configure Short-Time Synthesizer),
  • Command ScanRange (query or alter settings of existing scan range),
  • Command ScanRangeAdd (add new scan range).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eSTATE eState Enable or disable Short-Time Detector (Rx/FFM only; enabling in Scan Mode done by referring to parameter set ID).
    in int32 iStParamSetId Short-Time Detector parameter set ID: 0 for modes Rx and FFM, 1 to 64 for parameter sets available for assignment to a scan range.
    i/o eSTATE eStepAuto Select detector spectral step size (width of frequency channel) to be set automatically (depending on the IF panorama span: on) or manually (off). Ignored in Scan Mode: only manual setting of step with .eStep .
    i/o eSTD_STEP eStep Specify detector spectral step size. Note: Setting this parameter will disable (off) eStepAuto.
    i/o int64 iMinTime Set lower bound of range of signal durations [µs] (range 50 to 500000: 50 µs to 500 ms) the detector is to look for.
    out int64 iMinTimeCurrent Return current minimum duration [µs] used by the detector.
    out int64 iMinTimeGranularity Return minimal value [µs] by which minimum duration to be altered in order to change internally used minimum duration.
    i/o int64 iMaxTime Set upper bound of range of signal durations [µs] the detector is to look for (range: see iMinTime).
    out int64 iMaxTimeCurrent Return current maximum duration [µs] used by the detector.
    out int64 iMaxTimeGranularity Return minimal value [µs] by which maximum duration to be altered in order to change internally used maximum duration.
    i/o eSTATE eNoiseThresholdAuto Select noise threshold to be set automatically (on) or manually (off).
    i/o int32 iNoiseThreshold Set threshold [1/10 dB] (range 0 to 2000: 0 dB to 200 dB) for detector logic.
    i/o int64 iNoiseTime Set averaging time [µs] (range 1 to 10000000: 1 µs to 10 s) used for frequency dependent spectral noise level estimation of detector.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeDetector">
        <Param name="iStParamSetId">0</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeDetector">
        <Param name="eState">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="eStepAuto">STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="eStep">STD_STEP_390P63HZ</Param>
        <Param name="iMinTime">50</Param>
        <Param name="iMinTimeCurrent">500</Param>
        <Param name="iMinTimeGranularity">100</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTime">500000</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTimeCurrent">500000</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTimeGranularity">100</Param>
        <Param name="eNoiseThresholdAuto">STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="iNoiseThreshold">120</Param>
        <Param name="iNoiseTime">1000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeDetector">
        <Param name="eState">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="iStParamSetId">0</Param>
        <Param name="eStepAuto">STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="eStep">STD_STEP_390P63HZ</Param>
        <Param name="iMinTime">50</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTime">500000</Param>
        <Param name="eNoiseThresholdAuto">STATE_OFF</Param>
        <Param name="iNoiseThreshold">120</Param>
        <Param name="iNoiseTime">1000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeDetector">
        <Param name="iMinTimeCurrent">500</Param>
        <Param name="iMinTimeGranularity">100</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTimeCurrent">500000</Param>
        <Param name="iMaxTimeGranularity">100</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.10.5 ShortTimeSynthesizer

    GET: Query Short-Time Synthesizer parameters.
    SET: Configure Short-Time Synthesizer.
    Example: Short-Time Synthesizer on,
    IF signal bandwidth for all DDCs bound to it 30 kHz.

    NOTE 1: All modifications to input parameters are only taken over when performing a transition of ShortTimeSynthesizer.eState from OFF to ON.
    NOTE 2: ShortTimeSynthesizer must be enabled before enabling ShortTimeDetector .

    See also:
  • Command ShortTimeDetector (configure Short-Time Detector).
  • Command DDCEConfig (configure individual DDC).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eSTATE eState Enable or disable Short-Time Synthesizer (Rx/FFM only; in Scan Mode always active together with Short-Time Detector).
    i/o eSTS_BW eBandwidth Set IF signal bandwidth (30 kHz or 300 kHz) for all DDCs bound to Short-Time Synthesizer in total.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeSynthesizer">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeSynthesizer">
        <Param name="eState">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="eBandwidth">STS_BW_30000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeSynthesizer">
        <Param name="eState">STATE_ON</Param>
        <Param name="eBandwidth">STS_BW_30000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="ShortTimeSynthesizer">
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    1.11.2 AuxControl

    GET: Query mode and contents of AUX control port; port contents will be delivered to connector AUX, pin 28 to 35 (ANT_CTRL8 to ANT_CTRL1), to be used as antenna control signals.
    SET: Set mode and contents of AUX control port.
    Example: AUX control mode antenna,
    output value 7 to port (pin 28 to pin 32 reset, pin 33 to pin 35 set).

    Attention: Never insert signals from outside to the pins themselves!

    Name DDF550 DDF5GTS DDF1GTX RDDF3
    • AUX
    • X17
    • X17 (EBD)
    • X8
    • X17 (EBD)

    AUX control mode:

  • MANUAL:
    • Use entry of field AuxControl.iControlPortOutput.
  • FREQ:
    • Output current Rx frequency (frequency value in MHz) in BCD format.
    • If frequency value exceeds 99 MHz, its tens place and ones place are output, however: hundreds and higher places stay eliminated.
    • This output is adopted from other Rohde&Schwarz devices, its usefulness is limited from that.
  • ANTENNA:
    • Use settings of AntennaSetup, field AntennaSetup.iCtrlPort.

    See also:
  • Command AntennaSetup (specify antenna user setup, activate built-in GPS receiver).


    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eAUX_CTRL_MODE eControlPortMode Mode of AUX control port.
    i/o int32 iControlPortOutput Output to port (range 0 to 255) if mode is manual.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="AuxControl">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="AuxControl">
        <Param name="eControlPortMode">AUX_CTRL_MODE_ANTENNA</Param>
        <Param name="iControlPortOutput">7</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="AuxControl">
        <Param name="eControlPortMode">AUX_CTRL_MODE_ANTENNA</Param>
        <Param name="iControlPortOutput">7</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="AuxControl">
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.11.3 BlankingSettings

    GET: Query input and mode of operation of Blanking signal.
    SET: Specify input and operation.
    Conditions: Only with DF mode Rx (rejected with an error message if received in any other mode).
    Example: Blanking signal from connector AUX, pin 9 (BLANKING),
    Blanking mode Averaging (suppress antenna input signals with BLANKING active),
    BLANKING active low.


    Name DDF550 DDF5GTS DDF1GTX RDDF3
    • AUX
    • TRIGGER
    • X17
    • X44
    • X17 (EBD)
    • X44 (EBD)

    i/o eBLANKING_MODE eBlankingMode Blanking mode: suppress antenna inputs during active BLANKING signal, just indicate or ignore signal.
    i/o eBLANKING_POLARITY eBlankingPolarity Blanking polarity: active low or high.

    1.11.6 CorrectionState

    GET: Query currently used DF correction data.
    SET: Enable or disable DF correction data (which correction data sets / type of correction to be used).
    See R&S DDFx system manual and DF Error Correction manual for further information.
    Conditions: Only with DF mode Rx (rejected with an error message if received in any other mode).
    Example: Antenna factor correction in use,
    omniphase correction in use,
    cable attenuation in use,
    azimuth correction in use,
    attitude correction in use (consider nautical angles).

    Parameter CorrectionState.bCorrectAttitude does not insert additional correction data, but decides whether the nautical angles (ship deviations) be considered or not.

    This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o boolean bCorrectAntFactor Antenna factor correction (true: enabled, false: disabled).
    i/o boolean bCorrectOmniPhase Omniphase correction (ditto).
    i/o boolean bCorrectAttenuation Attenuation correction (ditto).
    i/o boolean bCorrectAzimuth Azimuth correction (ditto).
    i/o boolean bCorrectAttitude Attitude correction (true: consider nautical angles, false: do not consider).

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="CorrectionState">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="CorrectionState">
        <Param name="bCorrectAntFactor">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectOmniPhase">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAttenuation">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAzimuth">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAttitude">true</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="CorrectionState">
        <Param name="bCorrectAntFactor">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectOmniPhase">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAttenuation">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAzimuth">true</Param>
        <Param name="bCorrectAttitude">true</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="CorrectionState">
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    1.11.11 LanSettings

    GET: Query current LAN configuration of DDFx: IP address, default port, subnet mask etc.
    SET: Modify LAN configuration manually.
    Example: Current IP address:
  • 10.11.12.13,
  • default port 5555,
  • subnet mask 255.255.255.000,
  • gateway 10.11.12.13.
    • Static IP address:
  • 10.11.12.14,
  • default port 5555,
  • subnet mask 255.255.255.000,
  • gateway 10.11.12.13.
    • MTU size 1500,
    use DHCP address,
    hardware specific Ethernet address (MAC) 00-90-B8-10-01-15.

    192.168.255.253 and 192.168.255.254 are reserved IP addresses.

    This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o string zActIP Current IP address (24 chars max.).
    i/o int32 iActPort Current default port.
    i/o string zActSubnetmask Current subnet mask (24 chars max.).
    i/o string zActGateway Current gateway (24 chars max.).
    i/o string zPerIP Static IP address (24 chars max.).
    i/o int32 iPerPort Static default port.
    i/o string zPerSubnetmask Static subnet mask (24 chars max.).
    i/o string zPerGateway Static gateway (24 chars max.).
    i/o int32 iMTU Device MTU size [einheit].
    i/o boolean bUseDHCP Use DHCP or fixed (static) IP address (true: DHCP, false: static).
    out string zMacAddress Hardware specific Ethernet address (MAC) (24 chars max.).

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="LanSettings">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="LanSettings">
        <Param name="zActIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iActPort">5555</Param>
        <Param name="zActSubnetmask">255.255.255.000</Param>
        <Param name="zActGateway">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="zPerIP">10.11.12.14</Param>
        <Param name="iPerPort">5555</Param>
        <Param name="zPerSubnetmask">255.255.255.000</Param>
        <Param name="zPerGateway">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iMTU">1500</Param>
        <Param name="bUseDHCP">true</Param>
        <Param name="zMacAddress">00-90-B8-10-01-15</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="LanSettings">
        <Param name="zActIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iActPort">5555</Param>
        <Param name="zActSubnetmask">255.255.255.000</Param>

    1.11.13 LocationManual

    GET: Query current location: geographical latitude and longitude, altitude, geoidal separation.
    SET: Set location manually.
    Example: 48° 7' 38.3088" north (=48° 7.63848'),
    11° 36' 44.3556" east (=11° 36.73926'),
    540.6 m above sea level,
    geoidal separation 46.2 m,
    Munich.

    See also:
  • Command DateAndTime (set system time manually),
  • Command LocationAndTimeSource (set location and time source).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eDIRECTION eLatRef Latitude reference (north or south).
    i/o int32 eLatDeg Latitude degrees [°].
    i/o int32 eLatMin Latitude minutes [1/1000000 min].
    i/o eDIRECTION eLonRef Longitude reference (east or west).
    i/o int32 eLonDeg Longitude degrees [°].
    i/o int32 eLonMin Longitude minutes [1/1000000 min].
    i/o int32 iAltitude Altitude [cm] above MSL (Mean Sea Level).
    i/o boolean bGeoSepValid Geoidal separation (true: valid, false: invalid).
    i/o int32 iGeoSepValue Geoidal separation [cm]: height difference between "above WGS84 ellipsoid" and "above mean sea level": heightWGS84 = heightMSL + geoidalSeparation.
    i/o string zLocationName Name of location: user defined string (100 chars max.); arbitrary content only intended for user documentation, not for internal distinguishing of individual locations.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="LocationManual">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="LocationManual">
        <Param name="eLatRef">DIRECTION_NORTH</Param>
        <Param name="eLatDeg">48</Param>
        <Param name="eLatMin">7638480</Param>
        <Param name="eLonRef">DIRECTION_EAST</Param>
        <Param name="eLonDeg">11</Param>
        <Param name="eLonMin">36739260</Param>
        <Param name="iAltitude">54060</Param>
        <Param name="bGeoSepValid">true</Param>
        <Param name="iGeoSepValue">4620</Param>
        <Param name="zLocationName">Munich</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="LocationManual">
        <Param name="eLatRef">DIRECTION_NORTH</Param>
        <Param name="eLatDeg">48</Param>
        <Param name="eLatMin">7638480</Param>
        <Param name="eLonRef">DIRECTION_EAST</Param>
        <Param name="eLonDeg">11</Param>

    1.11.15 NmeaUdpPort

    GET: Query UDP port number (used for receiving NMEA 0183 sentences via UDP).
    SET: Set UDP port number.
    Example: UDP port number 10110.

    To send an NMEA 0183 sentence via UDP, store entire sentence (i.e. starting with '$' and ending with 'CR''LF') in UDP datagram.

    Sentences supported are (first 2 [unless noted otherwise] to 4 chars: unit ID, last 3 chars: type-of-data ID):

  • GPS:
    • GPGGA:
    • GPGSA:
    • GPS: Global Positioning System Fix Data (time, position and fixed related data for a GPS receiver)
    • GPS: GPS DOP ( dilution of precision) and active satellites
  • Navigation:
    • GPRMC:
    • GPS: Recommended Minimum Navigation Information, Type C
  • Heading:
    • HCHDG:
    • HCHDM:
    • HCHDT:
    • HCOSD:
    • Heading Compass: Heading Deviation & Variation
    • Heading Compass: Heading Magnetic
    • Heading Compass: Heading True
    • Heading Compass: Own Ship Data
  • Speed:
    • HCVHW:
    • Heading Compass: Water Speed and Heading
  • Proprietary:
    • PRSHRP:
    • PANZHRP:
    • Proprietary Rohde&Schwarz ( private identifier: 3 chars unit ID): heading, roll and pitch angle
    • Proprietary Anschütz ( private identifier: 4 chars unit ID): heading, roll and pitch angle

    See R&S DDFx system manual and relevant publications for more details on supported NMEA 0183 sentences.


    See also:
  • Enum eGPS_CODE (type of GPS receiver connected).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o int32 iPort UDP port number.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="NmeaUdpPort">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="NmeaUdpPort">
        <Param name="iPort">10110</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="NmeaUdpPort">
        <Param name="iPort">10110</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>

      </Command>

    1.11.18 Reset

    SET: Reset the R&S DDFx.
    Example: Perform a warm reset.

    NOTE: If the device is operating with external reference clock, a warm reset will switch it to internal clock; completing this switching will take some seconds. The actual reset (setting the default values) will only be executed after the (internal) reference oscillator has settled completely. Hence all user settings possibly performed between initiating and entirely having executed the reset will be void (overwritten).

    Available reset types:

  • SETTINGS RESET:
    • All device settings will be reset to their factory defaults, but R&S DDFx will keep on running (will not be rebooted).
  • WARM RESET:
    • Forces reboot of main processor, closes all communications interfaces, but does not reset the device settings to factory defaults.
    • A warm reset is useful for starting a firmware update procedure using the Update32 tool.
  • COLD RESET:
    • Forces reboot of main processor, closes all communications interfaces and resets all device settings to factory defaults.

    This command can be used as set command only.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    auto eRESET_TYPE eResetType Type of reset. (default value: RESET_WARM)

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="Reset">
        <Param name="eResetType">RESET_WARM</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="Reset">
        <Param name="eResetType">RESET_WARM</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.11.19 RfMode

    GET: Query RF mode (preselection mode).
    SET: Set RF (preselection) mode (see below).
    Example: Preselection mode Normal.

    Preselection mode with different Rx conditions:

    The Preselection module contains a selectable amplifier ahead of and one following each of the partly tuned range filters.

  • NORMAL:
    • Preselection filter active.
    • RF path settings optimized for both good noise figure and good high-level signal characteristics (Rx bandwidth limited ahead of the amplifier).
    • Recommended for standard Rx conditions.
  • LOW DISTORTION:
    • Preselection filter active; low noise amplifier (LNA, in case of frontend 4093.1514.08, see "LOW NOISE") bypassed.
    • Best linearity, but increases noise figure. RF path settings optimized for best large-signal immunity.
    • Especially recommended for areas with plenty of strong signals.
  • LOW NOISE:
    • Preselection filter not active; LNA instead of preselection filter active from 650 MHz up to improve noise figure at higher frequencies.
    • RF path settings optimized for best noise figure, but amplifier is hit by full signal power of antenna input. This weakens large-signal immunity, especially concerning 2nd degree interferences.
    • Strongly recommended for areas where no high-level signals exist in the input frequency range of 20 MHz to 6 GHz.
    • Restriction: only with frontend 4093.1514.08: R&S DDF550 and R&S DDF5GTS model 08/18. Not for HF Frequency Extension (options R&S DDF550-HF, R&S DDF550-HF2 and R&S DDFGTS-HF). Not for R&S DDF1GTX.

    This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eRF_MODE eRfMode Preselection mode.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="RfMode">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="RfMode">
        <Param name="eRfMode">RFMODE_NORMAL</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="RfMode">
        <Param name="eRfMode">RFMODE_NORMAL</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="RfMode">
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.11.20 TriggerSettings

    GET: Query mode(s) and source of triggered measurement.
    SET: Select mode(s) and source.
    Conditions: No scan ranges must be defined before entering trigger mode time synchronous scan ( TriggerSettings.eTriggerMode=DFTRIGGERMODE_TIMESYNC), thus first delete all existing scan ranges ( ScanRangeDeleteAll ).
    During antenna radiator test ( AntennaLevelSwitch.eAntLevelSwitch≠ANTLEVEL_OFF), trigger mode must be disabled ( TriggerSettings.eTriggerMode=DFTRIGGERMODE_DISABLED).
    Example: Triggered measurement disabled,
    trigger source is trigger,
    one single measurement per trigger event.

    See also:
  • Command ScanRangeDeleteAll (delete all existing scan ranges),
  • Command AntennaLevelSwitch (output of antenna level indications and switch antenna test radiator),
  • Enum eANTLEVELSWITCH (mode of antenna operation).

    • If the R&S DDFx has been set to a triggered measuring mode, a single measurement will be performed on any trigger event.

    This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    i/o eTRIGGER_MODE eTriggerMode Triggered measurement mode (disabled, external or Synchronous Scan).
    i/o eTRIGGER_SOURCE eTriggerSource Trigger source (external connector etc.).
    i/o eTRIGGER_MEASUREMODE eMeasureMode Measurement mode (single or continuous).

    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.12.7 TraceInfo

    GET: List all trace slots available with R&S DDFx (vacant and used).
    Example: Total number of 11 trace slots available:
    1st client:
  • on slot 1,
  • IP address 10.11.12.13,
  • local port 12345,
  • trace tags enabled IFPAN, ...,
  • selector flags enabled LEVEL, ...,
    • 2nd client:
  • ...
    		•

    This command can be used as get command only.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    out int32 iNoOfTraceSlots Total number of trace slots with R&S DDFx (vacant and used).
    out sTRACE_INFO asTraceInfo[20] All registered trace slots (20 max.).

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceInfo">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceInfo">
        <Param name="iNoOfTraceSlots">11</Param>
        <Array name="asTraceInfo">
          <Struct name="sTraceInfo">
            <Param name="iSlot">1</Param>
            <Param name="zIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
            <Param name="iPort">12345</Param>
            <Array name="aTraceTags">
              <Param name="eTraceTag">TRACETAG_IFPAN</Param>
              <!-- ... -->
            </Array>
            <Array name="aSelectorFlags">
              <Param name="eSelectorFlag">SELFLAG_LEVEL</Param>
              <!-- ... -->
            </Array>
          </Struct>
          <!-- ... -->
        </Array>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.12.8 TraceTcpTxBuffer

    GET: Query current size of TCP Tx buffer for this TCP connection.
    SET: Set current size of TCP Tx buffer for this TCP connection.
    Example: Set TCP Tx buffer size:
  • for host with IP address 10.11.12.13
  • for local port 12345
  • to 10 Mbyte.
    		•

    See also:
  • Command TraceTcpTxBufferPool (query size of portions of entire TCP Tx buffer pool).

    • This command can be used as get or set command.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    id string zIP IP address (24 chars max.) of client host.
    id int32 iPort Local port on client host.
    i/o int32 iTxBufferSize Size [bytes] of pool portion to be used for current TCP connection.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBuffer">
        <Param name="zIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iPort">12345</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBuffer">
        <Param name="zIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iPort">12345</Param>
        <Param name="iTxBufferSize">10000000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    Example

    SET command to the device:

    <Request type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBuffer">
        <Param name="zIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iPort">12345</Param>
        <Param name="iTxBufferSize">10000000</Param>
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the SET command from the device:

    <Reply type="set" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBuffer">
        <Param name="zIP">10.11.12.13</Param>
        <Param name="iPort">12345</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    1.12.9 TraceTcpTxBufferPool

    GET: Query current size of portions of entire TCP Tx buffer pool.
    Example: Get TCP Tx buffer size:
  • of entire TCP Tx buffer pool: 25 Mbyte
  • of pool portion currently in use for all TCP connections: 5.00736 Mbyte
  • of pool portion available for new TCP connections: 19.99264 Mbyte
    		•

    See also:
  • Command TraceTcpTxBuffer (read or set parameters for individual TCP Tx buffer).

    • This command can be used as get command only.

    ioType Datatype Member name Documentation
    out int32 iMaxPoolSize Size [bytes] of entire TCP Tx buffer pool.
    out int32 iUsedPoolSize Size [bytes] of pool portion in use for all TCP connections.
    out int32 iFreePoolSize Size [bytes] of pool portion available for new TCP connections.

    Example

    GET command to the device:

    <Request type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBufferPool">
      </Command>
    </Request>


    Answer to the GET command from the device:

    <Reply type="get" id="123">
      <Command name="TraceTcpTxBufferPool">
        <Param name="iMaxPoolSize">25000000</Param>
        <Param name="iUsedPoolSize">5007360</Param>
        <Param name="iFreePoolSize">19992640</Param>
      </Command>
    </Reply>

    back to top

    2.2 Struct: sFREQ_TIME_PAIR

    Frequency switch point: frequency that cannot be used inside a scan range if R&S DDFx is operated in Synchronous Scan mode (option R&S DDFx-TS, Time-Synchronous Scanning/Synchronization/Time Synchronization) (e.g. antenna switches over at this frequency).

    Frequency may only be used as start frequency of the scan range.

    Datatype Member name Documentation
    int64 iFrequency Frequency of switch point [Hz].
    int64 iTime Switching time [ns], indicates latency until DDFx is able to scan frequency.

    See also:

    • The Validity flags indicate the usable antenna properties:

    Flag Position Antenna usable as
    ANT_PAR_PASSIV 01 16 passive antenna
    ANT_PAR_ACTIVE 02 16 active antenna
    ANT_PAR_AFMODE 04 16 Rx antenna
    ANT_PAR_DFMODE 08 16 DF antenna
    ANT_PAR_VERT 10 16 linearly vertically polarized antenna
    ANT_PAR_HOR 20 16 linearly horizontally polarized antenna
    ANT_PAR_LEFT 40 16 circularly left-hand (counter-clockwise) polarized antenna
    ANT_PAR_RIGHT 80 16 circularly right-hand (clockwise) polarized antenna

    Datatype Member name Documentation
    int32 iAntNo Antenna number (used for backward compatibility).
    string sName Name of data record (usually corresponds to antenna model in AntennaRxDefine, 24 chars max.).
    int64 iFreqRangeBegin Lower border frequency [Hz] of antenna factors.
    int64 iFreqRangeEnd Upper border frequency [Hz].
    int32 iAntParams Validity flags (1: applies, 0: does not apply; see table above for details).

      3.17 Enum: eCLOCK_ORIGIN

      Origin of timing the data clock has been set to on latest setting.

      Some parameter settings apply only with options installed, e.g. option R&S DDFx-IGT, Integrated GPS Module.


      See also:
    • Command DateAndTime (query or set current system time),
    • Command LocationAndTimeSource (query current source of location and timing data or set source to GPS and back),
    • Command NTP (query timing information from NTP server and set as system time).

      • Value GuiValue Documentation
      CLOCK_ORIGIN_MANUAL Manual Timing data set manually (command DateAndTime).
      CLOCK_ORIGIN_BACKUP Real Time Clock Timing data set from internal RTC (Real Time Clock, battery-buffered, setting only with power-up).
      CLOCK_ORIGIN_GPS GPS Timing data set from external GPS receiver (or option R&S DDFx-IGT, Integrated GPS Module) to maintain continuity of clock time in periods of power-down (command LocationAndTimeSource.eLocTimeSource=LOC_TIME_SRC_GPS).
      CLOCK_ORIGIN_NTP Network Time Server Timing data set from external NTP (Network Time Protocol) server (command NTP).

      Utilization

      3.18 Enum: eCLOCK_START

      Mode of system clock start.

      Value Documentation
      CLOCK_START_AUTO Clock is started immediately upon setting (any pulse at PPS input ignored).
      CLOCK_START_EXTERNAL Clock is only started on pulse detected at PPS input (clock remains halted if such pulse missing).

      3.27 Enum: eDFPAN_SELECTIVITY

      Selectivity of DF panorama.

      Spectral selectivity generally equates to channel spacing (channel bandwidth); DFT length ensues from realtime bandwidth (frequency span) and this spacing. If needed, selectivity can be enhanced by a factor (twice or 4 times, i.e. spectral bins half or fourth as wide) by

    • gathering twice or 4 times as many sample values,
    • deploying a window function prolongated by this factor and then
    • transforming them to frequency domain by a DFT enhanced accordingly.

      • Waiting period for a new spectrum will hence be longer by the same factor.

      Value Documentation
      DFPAN_SELECTIVITY_AUTO Select automatically.
      DFPAN_SELECTIVITY_NORMAL Normal (factor 1, i.e. no prolongation).
      DFPAN_SELECTIVITY_NARROW Narrow (factor 2).
      DFPAN_SELECTIVITY_SHARP Sharp (factor 4).

      Utilization

      • Command MeasureSettingsFFM
      • Command ScanRange
      • Command ScanRangeAdd
      • Command ScanRangeNext
      • Command SearchRange
      • Command SearchRangeAdd
      • Command SearchRangeNext

      back to top
